text:
“Everybody
 is arguing whether or not it is a BAN. Call it what you want, it is 
about keeping bad people (with bad intentions) out of country!”
analysis:
Trump
 and his administration have quibbled with the news media’s use of the 
word “ban” to describe the executive order. But Trump himself called it a
 ban.

text:
“Do
 you believe it? The Obama Administration agreed to take thousands of 
illegal immigrants from Australia. Why? I will study this dumb deal!”
analysis:
Trump
 is referring to the estimated 1,250 (not “thousands”) refugees and 
asylum-seekers that the United States, under Obama, agreed to accept 
from an Australian detention center. Refugees and asylum-seekers who 
arrive illegally by boat in Australia are called “illegal maritime 
arrivals.” They can apply for two types of temporary visas, and some may
 qualify to apply for permanent residency.

text:
“Wow,
 @FoxNews just reporting big news. Source: 'Official behind unmasking is
 high up. Known Intel official is responsible. Some unmasked.... ..not 
associated with Russia. Trump team spied on before he was nominated.' If
 this is true, does not get much bigger. Would be sad for U.S.”
analysis:
Trump
 cited a rather vague Fox News report to allege spying by the Obama 
administration. But it appears to refers to national-security 
survelliance of foreign offcials that picked up references to U.S. 
citizens. Generally, those identities are masked, but officials can 
request the names in order to better understand the significance of the 
intelligence report.

text:
“When
 will Sleepy Eyes Chuck Todd and @NBCNews start talking about the Obama 
SURVEILLANCE SCANDAL and stop with the Fake Trump/Russia story?”
analysis:
The
 CIA concluded in 2016 that Russia intervened in the U.S. presidential 
election to help elect Trump, an assessment backed up by FBI Director 
James B. Comey and then-Director of National Intelligence James R. 
Clapper Jr. On Jan. 6, the intelligence community released a 
declassified report expressing "high confidence" in this judgement. 
Senate and House committees led by Republicans have begun their own 
investigations, and at least one Republican lawmaker has called for the 
appointment of a special prosecutor.

text:
“The
 failing @nytimes finally gets it - "In places where no insurance 
company offers plans, there will be no way for ObamaCare customers to.. 
...use subsidies to buy health plans." In other words, Ocare is dead. 
Good things will happen, however, either with Republicans or Dems.”
analysis:
The
 article cited by Trump noted that the Trump administration has the 
power to take steps that would mitigate the situation that Trump appears
 to celebrate.

text: “I am extremely pleased to see that @CNN has finally been exposed as #FakeNews and garbage journalism. It's about time!”
analysis: Unlike the creators of actual fake news, the editors of the retracted CNN article have resigned and been held to account.

text:
“Crazy
 Joe Scarborough and dumb as a rock Mika are not bad people, but their 
low rated show is dominated by their NBC bosses. Too bad!”
analysis:
According
 to {Ad Week}: "Morning Joe had a solid quarter in its own right. Not 
only did it defeat its rival [CNN] New Day in total viewers for the 9th 
straight quarter, but its 997,000 total viewer average represents a 
quarterly audience record for MSNBC in the 6 – 9 a.m. time period." 
After Trump attacked the hosts on Twitter, the show broke its ratings 
record.

text: “Numerous states are refusing to give information to the very distinguished VOTER FRAUD PANEL. What are they trying to hide?”
analysis:
States
 refused to turn over voter information to the voting commission over 
concerns that doing so may violate federal and state privacy laws. Yet 
Trump suggests that states deciding not to share the information are up 
to something nefarious.

text:
Stock
 Market could hit all-time high (again) 22,000 today. Was 18,000 only 6 
months ago on Election Day. Mainstream media seldom mentions!
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before he was elected, he dismissed the 
stock-market performance under Obama as “artificial” and “a bubble."

text:
“Only
 the Fake News Media and Trump enemies want me to stop using Social 
Media (110 million people). Only way for me to get the truth out!”
analysis: Polls consistently show that even Trump supporters are alarmed by the president's Twitter habits.

text: “Stock Market up 5 months in a row!”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before he was elected, he dismissed the 
stock-market performance under Obama as “artificial” and “a bubble."

text:
“All
 buildings now inspected........for safety. Thank you to the Governor of
 P.R. and to all of those who are working so closely with our First 
Responders. Fantastic job!”
analysis:
“I’m
 not aware of such inspection. Of course, there are areas of Puerto Rico
 which we haven’t really gotten in contact. Perhaps he was referring to a
 particular set of buildings. I’m not sure," said Puerto Rican Gov. Ricardo Rossello.

text:
“Being
 nice to Rocket Man hasn't worked in 25 years, why would it work now? 
Clinton failed, Bush failed, and Obama failed. I won't fail.”
analysis:
This
 is an odd statement. Trump uses the "Rocket Man" nickname for Kim 
Jong-Un. It's unclear whether Trump knows that there have been three 
North Korean leaders since Bill Clinton's presidency, all with the last 
name Kim. It's a misleading claim that the past three presidents have 
"all been outplayed by this gentleman." It's actually three men in the 
same Kim family: Kim Il-Sung, Kim Jong-Il and Kim Jong-Un. Clinton, Bush
 and Obama would dispute that they were "nice" to North Korean leaders.

text:
“If
 U.C. Berkeley does not allow free speech and practices violence on 
innocent people with a different point of view - NO FEDERAL FUNDS?”
analysis: This is not how federal funding for public universities works.

text:
“Iran
 was on its last legs and ready to collapse until the U.S. came along 
and gave it a life-line in the form of the Iran Deal: $150 billion”
analysis:
Trump
 always uses too high an estimate, $150 billion, and makes it sound like
 the United States cut a check to Iran. But this was always Iran’s 
money. Iran had billions of dollars in assets that were frozen in 
foreign banks around the globe because of international sanctions over 
its nuclear program. The Treasury Department estimated that once Iran 
fulfilled other obligations, it would have about $55 billion left. The 
Central Bank of Iran said the number was actually $32 billion. And it's a
 stretch to say Iran was "ready to collapse.”

text:
“Since
 November 8th, Election Day, the Stock Market has posted $3.2 trillion 
in GAINS and consumer confidence is at a 15 year high.”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before he was elected, he dismissed the 
stock-market performance under Obama as “artificial” and “a bubble."

text: “#FraudNewsCNN #FNN https://t.co/WYUnHjjUjg”
analysis: Unlike the creators of actual fake news, the editors of the retracted CNN article have resigned and been held to account.

text:
“Stock
 Market at all time high, unemployment at lowest level in years (wages 
will start going up) and our base has never been stronger!”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Trump equates the rise of the stock market 
since the election as a demonstration of a good economy. But the stock 
market had already been rising for years before he was elected — and he 
called it “a big, fat, ugly bubble.”

text:
“Professional
 anarchists, thugs and paid protesters are proving the point of the 
millions of people who voted to MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN!”
analysis:
Trump
 seems to be citing a segment of Sean Hannity’s show, during which 
Hannity questioned whether there was a paid effort to galvanize 
protesters showing up at airports in the wake of Trump’s immigration 
executive order. But there’s no evidence there were paid protesters at 
airports. There were reports that a group called “Demand Protest” was 
paying people to protest against Trump on the day of his inauguration, 
but Snopes.com debunked that claim.

text:
“Countries
 charge U.S. companies taxes or tariffs while the U.S. charges them 
nothing or little.We should charge them SAME as they charge us!”
analysis:
Many
 countries — but not the United States — have a value-added tax, in 
which tax is collected at each stage in the production or distribution 
of a product or service. But with refunds, the burden is really paid by 
the final consumer. Moreover, the VAT also affects domestic producers. 
In terms of tariffs, it is incorrect the United States charges “nothing 
or little.” The United States imposes tariffs on Chinese goods, but they
 are not as high as Chinese tariffs on U.S. goods.

text: “We should start an immediate investigation into @SenSchumer and his ties to Russia and Putin. A total hypocrite!”
analysis:
Trump
 makes a misleading comparison between Attorney General Jeff Sessions's 
meetings with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak and Sen. Charles E. 
Schumer's meeting Vladimir Putin at a pu blic event in 2003. Sessions, 
who was a Trump campaign surrogate, misled Congress by not disclosing 
that he met with Kislyak on at least two occasions during the 2016 
presidential campaign, including one private meeting at Sessions's 
Senate office.

text: “I hereby demand a second investigation, after Schumer, of Pelosi for her close ties to Russia, and lying about it.”
analysis:
Trump
 makes a misleading comparison between Attorney General Jeff Sessions's 
meetings with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak and Rep. Nancy Pelosi's 
2010 meeting with then-Russian President Dmitry Medvedev. Sessions, a 
Trump campaign surrogate, misled Congress by not disclosing that he met 
with Kislyak on at least two occasions during the 2016 presidential 
campaign, including one private meeting at Sessions's Senate office. 
Pelosi and other House leaders met with Medvedev, who brought Kislyak 
and other top Russian officials to the meeting.

text: “It is so pathetic that the Dems have still not approved my full Cabinet.”
analysis:
The
 Senate Democrats did hold up Trump's Cabinet picks at one time. But as 
of Trump's tweet, there were two empty slots; the administration had not
 sent the rest of the paperwork for one and had not sent a nominee to 
fill the other slot. Sen. Marco Rubio tweeted
 the prior evening, on March 2: "After the votes taken earlier this 
afternoon, the U.S. Senate has now confirmed all of the available 
Cabinet nominations."

text: “Did Hillary Clinton ever apologize for receiving the answers to the debate? Just asking!”
analysis:
Trump
 overstates the disclosure about Clinton reportedly getting a single 
debate question. During the Democratic primaries, a debate was held in 
Flint, Mich., to focus on the water crisis. Donna Brazile, then a CNN 
analyst, sent an email to the Clinton campaign saying that a woman with a
 rash from lead poisoning was going to ask what Clinton as president 
could do the help the people of Flint. There’s no indication Clinton was
 told this information, but in any case it’s a pretty obvious question 
for a debate being held in Flint.

text:
“.@FoxNews
 from multiple sources: "There was electronic surveillance of Trump, and
 people close to Trump. This is unprecedented." @FBI”
analysis:
Trump
 cited a Fox News report to allege spying by the Obama administration. 
But it appears to refers to national-security survelliance of foreign 
offcials that picked up references to U.S. citizens. Generally, those 
identities are masked, but officials can request the names in order to 
better understand the significance of the intelligence report.

text:
“We
 need to be smart, vigilant and tough. We need the courts to give us 
back our rights. We need the Travel Ban as an extra level of safety!”
analysis:
Trump
 tweeted this in response to the deadly attacks on June 3 on the London 
Bridge and Borough Market. But this tweet is misleading. The U.K. is not
 among the six countries identified in his "travel ban," or the 
immigration executive order.

text:
“Business
 is looking better than ever with business enthusiasm at record levels. 
Stock Market at an all-time high. That doesn't just happen!”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before he was elected, he dismissed the 
stock-market performance under Obama as “artificial” and “a bubble."

text:
“The
 United States is considering, in addition to other options, stopping 
all trade with any country doing business with North Korea.”
analysis:
This
 is clearly an idle threat, given that China by far is North Korea's 
trading partner. In 2016, the United States sold $116 billion in goods 
to China and purchased $462 billion, so a sudden cut-off of "all trade" 
would be devastating to the U.S. economy.

text:
“It
 is a 'miracle' how fast the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police were able to 
find the demented shooter and stop him from even more killing!”
analysis: The shooter had committed suicide by the time the police arrived at his room.

text:
“After
 being forced to apologize for its bad and inaccurate coverage of me 
after winning the election, the FAKE NEWS @nytimes is still lost!”
analysis:
The
 Times did not apologize to its subscribers for its coverage of Trump. 
Both the Times and The Post have seen spikes in audience and 
subscribers.

text:
“Interesting
 that certain Middle-Eastern countries agree with the ban. They know if 
certain people are allowed in it's death & destruction!”
analysis:
Trump
 appears to referring to a news story he posted on his Facebook account —
 that Kuwait had issued “its own Trump-esque visa ban for five 
Muslim-majority countries.” Trump added: “Smart!” But it turned out this
 was fake news. Kuwait “categorically denies these claims,” the 
country’s foreign ministry said. Trump’s Facebook post has not been 
taken down.

text:
“What
 is our country coming to when a judge can halt a Homeland Security 
travel ban and anyone, even with bad intentions, can come into U.S.?”
analysis:
Trump
 tweeted a number of critical comments about the “so-called judge” who 
halted the president’s travel ban of citizens from seven Muslim-majority
 countries. The judiciary was established in the U.S. Constitution as a 
third branch of government (along with the executive and legislative 
branches), part of the complex system of checks and balances that 
ensures the continuation of democracy. Marbury v. Madison, a Supreme 
Court case decided more than 200 years ago, helped establish the notion 
of judicial review and cemented the notion that the judiciary was equal 
in power to the president and Congress.

text: “Because the ban was lifted by a judge, many very bad and dangerous people may be pouring into our country. A terrible decision”
analysis:
There
 is little evidence that the ruling halting Trump’s order has allowed 
“very bad and dangerous people” to pour into the country. The practical 
effect of the order was to restore visas and refugee admissions. Being 
accepted as a refugee in the United States is a difficult, lengthy 
process. Obtaining a U.S. visa generally requires an in-person 
interview, unless you are a citizen of one of 38 countries that 
participate in the visa-waiver program. Under a 2015 law, however, four 
of the seven countries covered in the ban require even dual citizens to 
have an in-person interview.

text:
“How
 low has President Obama gone to tapp my phones during the very sacred 
election process. This is Nixon/Watergate. Bad (or sick) guy!”
analysis:
There
 is no evidence that Obama ordered the wiretapping of Trump's calls. 
Trump seized on reports in the right-leaning media, but even the reports
 cited by the White House did not make this allegation. Fact Checker rating:

text:
“Terrible!
 Just found out that Obama had my 'wires tapped' in Trump Tower just 
before the victory. Nothing found. This is McCarthyism!”
analysis:
There
 is no evidence that Obama ordered the wiretapping of Trump's calls. 
Trump seized on reports in the right-leaning media, but even the reports
 cited by the White House did not make this allegation. Fact Checker rating:

text:
“Is
 it legal for a sitting President to be 'wire tapping' a race for 
president prior to an election? Turned down by court earlier. A NEW 
LOW!”
analysis:
There
 is no evidence that Obama ordered the wiretapping of Trump's calls. 
Trump seized on reports in the right-leaning media, but even the reports
 cited by the White House did not make this allegation. Fact Checker rating:

text:
“I'd
 bet a good lawyer could make a great case out of the fact that 
President Obama was tapping my phones in October, just prior to 
Election!”
analysis:
There
 is no evidence that Obama ordered the wiretapping of Trump's calls. 
Trump seized on reports in the right-leaning media, but even the reports
 cited by the White House did not make this allegation. Fact Checker rating:

text:
“Just
 out: The same Russian Ambassador that met Jeff Sessions visited the 
Obama White House 22 times, and 4 times last year alone.”
analysis:
This
 is a misleading comparison. Sessions appears to have misled the Senate 
about his meetings, while the meetings at the White House were recorded 
in a public log that Trump has now eliminated.

text:
“Arnold
 Schwarzenegger isn't voluntarily leaving the Apprentice, he was fired 
by his bad (pathetic) ratings, not by me. Sad end to great show.”
analysis:
Schwarzenegger
 said he was leaving of his own accord, blaming animus toward Trump for 
the show's sagging ratings. “You should think about hiring a new joke 
writer and a fact checker," Schwarenegger tweeted back.

text:
Death spiral!
'Aetna will exit Obamacare markets in VA in 2018, citing expected losses on INDV plans this year'
analysis:
The
 Affordable Care Act is not on a "death spiral" and is expected to 
remain stable for the foreseeable future, according to the Congressional
 Budget Office.

text: “At least 7 dead and 48 wounded in terror attack and Mayor of London says there is 'no reason to be alarmed!'”
analysis:
Trump
 takes London Mayor Sadiq Khan's comments totally out of context, making
 it seem as though Khan was playing down the deadly attacks on June 3 on
 the London Bridge and Borough Market. Khan said there is "no reason to 
be alarmed" about the increased police presence following the attacks. 
Khan condemned the attacks: "I am appalled and furious that these 
cowardly terrorists would deliberately target innocent Londoners and 
bystanders enjoying their Saturday night."

text: “Gas prices are the lowest in the U.S. in over ten years! I would like to see them go even lower.”
analysis:
Trump
 is walking a fine line here. As our friends at PolitiFact noted, {gas 
prices were lower than anytime since 2005} over July fourth weekend, but
 in fact, when adjusted for inflation, they have been lower than they 
are now at several points over the last ten years.

text:
“Toyota
 & Mazda to build a new $1.6B plant here in the U.S.A. and create 4K
 new American jobs. A great investment in American manufacturing! 
....and don't forget that Foxconn will be spending up to 10 billion 
dollars on a top of the line plant/plants in Wisconsin.”
analysis:
Trump
 keeps taking credit for projects that were long in the works before he 
became president. For example, he repeatedly claims credit for Ford’s 
decision to abandon its plans to open a factory in Mexico and instead 
expand its Michigan plant. But analysts say Ford’s decision has more to 
do with the company’s long-term goal — particularly, its plans to invest
 in electric vehicles — than the administration. Foxconn considered 
investing in U.S.-based facilities since 2014, though its initial plans 
to invest in Pennsylvania didn't pan out. Trump keeps celebrating the 
company's decision, but the Wisconsin Legislature had not yet approved 
the $3 billion incentives package amid concerns from taxpayers. Fact Checker rating:
Job growth in the first six months of Trump's presidency has been slower than the same period of the previous five years.

text:
“Is
 it true the DNC would not allow the FBI access to check server or other
 equipment after learning it was hacked? Can that be possible?”
analysis:
The
 FBI and the Democratic National Committee disagree on whether the FBI 
requested access to the DNC's servers. FBI Director James Comey 
testified to the Senate Intelligence Committee that the bureau made 
"multiple requests at different levels" to access DNC's servers, but the
 DNC said the FBI never requested access. The DNC ultimately allowed a 
private company to review its database and share findings with the FBI.

text: “Thank you for the great rallies all across the country. Tremendous support. Make America Great Again!”
analysis:
The
 size of crowds holding "March 4 Trump" rallies varied, from about 30 
people in Indianapolis to about 400 in St. Paul, Minn. Some rallies drew
 just as many protesters as supporters.

text:
“Rather
 than causing a big disruption in N.Y.C., I will be working out of my 
home in Bedminster, N.J. this weekend. Also saves country money!”
analysis:
The
 White House made it hard for taxpayers to learn much about travel costs
 and there is no evidence that working in New Jersey rather than 
Manhattan actually saves much money.

text:
“Of
 course the Australians have better healthcare than we do --everybody 
does. ObamaCare is dead! But our healthcare will soon be great.
analysis:
The
 Affordable Care Act is not on a "death spiral" and is expected to 
remain stable for the foreseeable future, according to the Congressional
 Budget Office.

text:
“Why
 is it that the Fake News rarely reports Ocare is on its last legs and 
that insurance companies are fleeing for their lives? It's dead!
analysis:
The
 Affordable Care Act is not on a "death spiral" and is expected to 
remain stable for the foreseeable future, according to the Congressional
 Budget Office.

text:
“Pathetic
 excuse by London Mayor Sadiq Khan who had to think fast on his "no 
reason to be alarmed" statement. MSM is working hard to sell it!”
analysis:
Trump
 doubles down on taking London Mayor Sadiq Khan's comments out of 
context, making it seem as though Khan was playing down the deadly 
attacks on June 3 on the London Bridge and Borough Market. Khan said 
there is "no reason to be alarmed" about the increased police presence 
following the attacks. Khan condemned the attacks: "I am appalled and 
furious that these cowardly terrorists would deliberately target 
innocent Londoners and bystanders enjoying their Saturday night."

text:
“People,
 the lawyers and the courts can call it whatever they want, but I am 
calling it what we need and what it is, a TRAVEL BAN!”
analysis:
Trump
 now insists that his immigration executive order is a "travel ban," and
 criticized others who used other terms to describe it. But this lacks 
context. His own administration repeatedly said the term "travel ban" 
misrepresents the executive order, and insisted that the immigration 
order is not, in fact, a "travel ban."

text:
“That's
 right, we need a TRAVEL BAN for certain DANGEROUS countries, not some 
politically correct term that won't help us protect our people!”
analysis:
Trump
 now insists that his immigration executive order is a "travel ban," and
 criticized others who used other terms to describe it. But this lacks 
context. His own administration repeatedly said the term "travel ban" 
misrepresents the executive order, and insisted that the immigration 
order is not, in fact, a "travel ban."

text:
“The
 Justice Dept. should ask for an expedited hearing of the watered down 
Travel Ban before the Supreme Court - & seek much tougher version!”
analysis:
Trump
 now insists that his immigration executive order is a "travel ban," and
 criticized others who used other terms to describe it. But this lacks 
context. His own administration repeatedly said the term "travel ban" 
misrepresents the executive order, and insisted that the immigration 
order is not, in fact, a "travel ban." Moreover, Trump decided to 
abandon the original version of the "travel ban," or the immigration 
executive order.

text:
“The
 Justice Dept. should have stayed with the original Travel Ban, not the 
watered down, politically correct version they submitted to S.C.”
analysis:
Trump
 now insists that his immigration executive order is a "travel ban," and
 criticized others who used other terms to describe it. But this lacks 
context. His own administration repeatedly said the term "travel ban" 
misrepresents the executive order, and insisted that the immigration 
order is not, in fact, a "travel ban." Moreover, Trump decided to 
abandon the original version of the "travel ban," or the immigration 
executive order.

text:
“Stock
 Market hits an ALL-TIME high! Unemployment lowest in 16 years! Business
 and manufacturing enthusiasm at highest level in decades!”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before he was elected, he dismissed the 
stock-market performance under Obama as “artificial” and “a bubble." It 
is also a flip-flop to cite an unemployment rate he used to denounce as 
phony.

text:
“Why
 Isn't the Senate Intel Committee looking into the Fake News Networks in
 OUR country to see why so much of our news is just made up-FAKE!”
analysis: Trump appears to associate negative news reports as fake news. but that's not how the First Amendment works.

text:
“Ralph
 Northam,who is running for Governor of Virginia,is fighting for the 
violent MS-13 killer gangs & sanctuary cities.  Vote Ed Gillespie!”
analysis: There are no sanctuary cities in Virginia. Northam does not support MS-13 gangs.

text:
“Any
 negative polls are fake news, just like the CNN, ABC, NBC polls in the 
election. Sorry, people want border security and extreme vetting.”
analysis:
This
 odd tweet appeared aimed at reassuring Trump supporters after polls 
from CBS News, CNN/ORC, Gallup and Quinnipiac University showed 
majorities of Americans opposed to the order and its provisions. (Other 
polls indicated support for Trump’s order.) In the 2016 presidential 
election, while polls played down Trump’s chances of winning the 
electoral college, most nationwide polls actually were close to mark. 
The RealClearPolitics average showed Clinton ahead by 2.1 percentage 
points — exactly the margin she achieved in her popular-vote victory.

text:
“The
 failing @nytimes was forced to apologize to its subscribers for the 
poor reporting it did on my election win. Now they are worse!”
analysis:
The
 Times did not apologize to its subscribers for its coverage of Trump. 
Both the Times and The Post have seen spikes in audience and 
subscribers.

text: “Buy American & hire American are the principals at the core of my agenda, which is: JOBS, JOBS, JOBS!”
analysis:
Trump
 has a long history of outsourcing a variety of his own products. The 
Fact Checker has counted a total of 12 countries where Trump products 
were manufactured (China, the Netherlands, Mexico, India, Turkey, 
Slovenia, Honduras, Germany, Bangladesh, Indonesia, Vietnam and South 
Korea).

text:
“45,000
 construction & manufacturing jobs in the U.S. Gulf Coast region. 
$20 billion investment [by ExxonMobil]. We are already winning again, 
America!”
analysis:
Trump
 again takes credit for a project long in the works before he became 
president. ExxonMobil has been planning this since 2013.

text:
“The
 reason I am staying in Bedminster, N. J., a beautiful community, is 
that staying in NYC is much more expensive and disruptive. Meetings!”
analysis: Trump claimed he was at the Trump golf club in Bedminster, N.J., for "Meetings!" but an Instagram user captured a photo of him playing golf that day.

text:
“Insurance
 companies are fleeing ObamaCare - it is dead. Our healthcare plan will 
lower premiums & deductibles - and be great healthcare!”
analysis:
The
 Congressional Budget Office analysis of the bill said that premiums 
would be ten percent lower than projected by 2026, not that they would 
actually be reduced. The main reason is that insurance would become more
 costly for older, sicker Americans and they would drop health 
insurance, resulting in a pool of younger, healthier people, the CBO 
said.

text:
“The
 reason I am staying in Bedminster, N. J., a beautiful community, is 
that staying in NYC is much more expensive and disruptive. Meetings!”
analysis:
The
 White House made it hard for taxpayers to learn much about travel costs
 and there is no evidence that working in New Jersey rather than 
Manhattan actually saves much money. As for meetings, a photo later 
emerged of Trump playing golf at his club.

text: “We are the highest taxed nation in the world - that will change.”
analysis:
Trump
 almost never gets this correct. The Pew Research Center, using 2014 
data, found that the tax bill for Americans, under various scenarios, is
 below average for developed countries. In 2014, according to 
comparative tables of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and 
Development (OECD), revenue as a percentage of the gross domestic 
product — the broadest measure of the economy — was 26 percent for the 
United States. Out of 34 countries, that put the United States in the 
bottom third — and well below the OECD average of 34.4 percent.Fact Checker rating:

text:
“Since
 Election Day on November 8, the Stock Market is up more than 25%, 
unemployment is at a 17 year low & companies are coming back to 
U.S.”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before he was elected, he dismissed the 
stock-market performance under Obama as “artificial” and “a bubble." It 
is also a flip-flop to cite an unemployment rate he used to denounce as 
phony.

text:
“I
 don't know Putin, have no deals in Russia, and the haters are going 
crazy - yet Obama can make a deal with Iran, #1 in terror, no problem!”
analysis:
Trump
 now claims he doesn’t know Russian President Vladimir Putin, but in the
 past, he had claimed he had spoken to him. Trump’s assertion he has “no
 deals in Russia” is misleading at best, since Trump has actively 
pursued deals there and has relied on Russia investors. As for the 
nuclear agreement with Iran, that agreement was forged with the 
assistance of diplomats from the United Kingdom, France, Germany, China,
 Russia and the European Union. Obama did not negotiate it alone.

text:
“It
 is a disgrace that my full Cabinet is still not in place, the longest 
such delay in the history of our country. Obstruction by Democrats!”
analysis:
This
 is false. Bill Clinton did not have a cabinet in place until March 11, 
George H.W. Bush had to wait till March 17 and Obama did not get a full 
cabinet until April 28. Trump would not have grounds to complain that at
 this point he has fewer Cabinet members confirmed than his 
predecessors. While Democrats have put up roadblocks, part of the reason
 for the delay is because paperwork has been slow in coming from some of
 Trump’s wealthier nominees.

text:
“122
 vicious prisoners, released by the Obama Administration from Gitmo, 
have returned to the battlefield. Just another terrible decision!" 
(@realDonaldTrump account)
analysis:
This
 is false. Only eight former Gitmo detainees "confirmed of reengaging" 
in terrorist or insurgent activities were released under Obama, and 113 
were released under George W. Bush. Although this tweet, sent at 7:04 
a.m., was immediately called out as false on Twitter, Trump repeated it 
on the @POTUS account at 8:03 a.m.  Trump tweeted this on the same day 
from @realDonaldTrump and @POTUS. Therefore, we are counting the two 
tweets as separate entries in our database.

text:
“122
 vicious prisoners, released by the Obama Administration from Gitmo, 
have returned to the battlefield. Just another terrible decision!" 
(@POTUS account)
analysis:
This
 is false. Only eight former Gitmo detainees "confirmed of reengaging" 
in terrorist or insurgent activities were released under Obama, and 113 
were released under George W. Bush. Trump first tweeted this at 7:04 
a.m. on the @realDonaldTrump account, and it was immediately called out 
as false on Twitter. But then at 8:03 a.m., he repeated the same tweet 
on the @POTUS account. Therefore, we are counting the two tweets as 
separate entries in our database.

text:
“When
 will the Fake Media ask about the Dems dealings with Russia & why 
the DNC wouldn't allow the FBI to check their server or investigate?”
analysis:
The
 FBI and the Democratic National Committee disagree on whether the FBI 
requested access to the DNC's servers. FBI Director James Comey 
testified to the Senate Intelligence Committee that the bureau made 
"multiple requests at different levels" to access DNC's servers, but the
 DNC said the FBI never requested access. The DNC ultimately allowed a 
private company to review its database and share findings with the FBI.

text:
“Republican
 Senators will not let the American people down! ObamaCare premiums and 
deductibles are way up - it was a lie and it is dead!”
analysis:
The
 Affordable Care Act is not on a "death spiral" and is expected to 
remain stable for the foreseeable future, according to the Congressional
 Budget Office.

text:
“Rexnord
 of Indiana made a deal during the Obama Administration to move to 
Mexico. Fired their employees. Tax product big that's sold in U.S.”
analysis:
This
 was announced after Trump was elected and when he was making a show of 
saving jobs at another Indiana company. Yet now he blames Obama.

text: “Everyone here is talking about why John Podesta refused to give the DNC server to the FBI and the CIA. Disgraceful!”
analysis:
The
 FBI and the Democratic National Committee disagree on whether the FBI 
requested access to the DNC's servers. FBI Director James Comey 
testified to the Senate Intelligence Committee that the bureau made 
"multiple requests at different levels" to access DNC's servers, but the
 DNC said the FBI never requested access. The DNC ultimately allowed a 
private company to review its database and share findings with the FBI.

text:
“The
 failing @nytimes, which has made every wrong prediction about me 
including my big election win (apologized), is totally inept!”
analysis:
The
 Times did not apologize to its subscribers for its coverage of Trump. 
The Times has seen spikes in audience and subscribers.

text:
“The
 Trump base is far bigger &  stronger than ever before (despite some
 phony Fake News polling). Look at rallies in Penn, Iowa, Ohio.... and 
West Virginia. The fact is the Fake News Russian collusion story, record
 Stock Market, border security, military strength, jobs..... Supreme 
Court pick, economic enthusiasm, deregulation & so much more have 
driven the Trump base even closer together. Will never change!”
analysis:
Trump's
 approval rating is the worse for any recent new president, and polls 
increasingly indicate a decline in support among people who voted for 
him.

text: “Hard to believe that with 24/7 #Fake News on CNN, ABC, NBC, CBS, NYTIMES & WAPO, the Trump base is getting stronger!”
analysis:
Trump's
 approval rating is the worse for any recent new president, and polls 
increasingly indicate a decline in support among people who voted for 
him.

text:
“Never
 in U.S.history has anyone lied or defrauded voters like Senator Richard
 Blumenthal. He told stories about his Vietnam battles and....conquests,
 how brave he was, and it was all a lie. He cried like a baby and begged
 for forgiveness like a child. Now he judges collusion?”
analysis:
Blumenthal
 did misrepresent his military service, repeatedly conflating his time 
in the Marine Reserves in Washington, D.C., with those who served 
overseas in Vietnam, and later apologized. But there is no evidence he 
ever bragged about conquests or battles or that he cried when his 
misleading statements became public.

text:
“More
 and more people are suggesting that Republicans (and me) should be 
given Equal Time on T.V. when you look at the one-sided coverage.”
analysis:
The
 Fairness Doctrine, which required broadcasters to air contrasting views
 regarding controversial matters of public interest, was repealed in 
1987 during the Reagan administration. The repeal helped foster the rise
 of right-leaning television and radio programs, presumably a 
development the president supports.

text: “Bob Corker gave us the Iran Deal, & that's about it.”
analysis: Sen. Corker (R-Tenn.) opposed the Iran deal negotiated by President Obama.

text:
“My
 daughter Ivanka has been treated so unfairly by @Nordstrom. She is a 
great person -- always pushing me to do the right thing! Terrible!”
analysis:
There
 is no evidence that Nordstrom acted out of political considerations. 
The company has maintained for months (including in internal emails) 
that it will base its decisions on sales performance. Internal records 
reviewed by the Wall Street Journal show the sales of Ivanka Trump's 
brand fell 32 percent at Nordstrom last fiscal year.Fact Checker rating:

text:
“LinkedIn
 Workforce Report: January and February were the strongest consecutive 
months for hiring since August and September 2015”
analysis:
Trump
 failed to read the fine print of the LinkedIn Workforce report. The 
numbers were affected by seasonal hiring. When adjusted for seasonal 
hiring variations, hiring was down 1.3 percent from January to February,
 the first full month of Trump's term.

text:
“Director
 Clapper reiterated what everybody, including the fake media already 
knows- there is "no evidence" of collusion w/ Russia and Trump.”
analysis:
Trump
 goes too far in attributing such a comment to James Clapper, the former
 director of national intelligence (DNI). Clapper told the Senate 
Judiciary Committee that he was not aware of evidence showing collusion 
between members of the Trump campaign and the Russians. Clapper also 
said he was not aware of the FBI's investigation into the collusion 
until then-FBI Director James Comey revealed it on March 20, 2017. The 
FBI director has discretion to keep such counterintelligence 
investigations closely held, and only notify the DNI when appropriate, 
Clapper said.

text:
“Our
 incredible U.S. Coast Guard saved more than 15,000 lives last week with
 Harvey. Irma could be even tougher. We love our Coast Guard!”
analysis: The Coast Guard announced it rescued 11,022 people in its Hurricane Harvey response.

text:
“Senator
 Bob Corker 'begged' me to endorse him for re-election in Tennessee. I 
said 'NO' and he dropped out (said he could not win without my 
endorsement.”
analysis:
Todd
 Womack, Corker's chief of staff, disputed each of the claims the 
president made in his tweets. Trump called Corker early last week and 
asked him to reconsider his decision not to seek reelection, according 
to Womack. He said the president also reaffirmed that he would have 
endorsed Corker had he decided to run again — which, Womack added, was 
not the first time that Trump had extended such an offer of support.

text:
“Our
 country has been unsuccessfully dealing with North Korea for 25 years, 
giving billions of dollars & getting nothing. Policy didn't work!”
analysis:
Under
 the Bill Clinton accord with North Korea, between 1995 and 2003 the 
United States spent about $400 million supplying the fuel oil to North 
Korea that was required under the deal. An international consortium 
spent about $2.5 billion to replace the North’s plutonium reactor with 
two light-water reactors; the project was not completed before the deal 
collapsed by the money mostly went to South Korean and Japanese 
companies, not North Korea. The United States stopped paying food 
assistance to North Korea after 2011, with the exception of $1 million 
in humanitarian aid in January 2017 that was negotiated by outgoing 
Secretary of State John Kerry just before Trump was inaugurated. Total 
food assistance since 1995 was about $700 million. George W. Bush in 
2007-2008 provided about $150 million in fuel oil when engaged in 
negotiations.

text:
“Sen.Richard
 Blumenthal, who never fought in Vietnam when he said for years he had 
(major lie),now misrepresents what Judge Gorsuch told him?”
analysis:
Trump
 is wrong that the Connecticut Democrat had misrepresented Gorsuch’s 
remarks. Blumenthal’s account was immediately confirmed by Ron Bonjean, a
 member of the group guiding the judge through his confirmation process 
on behalf of the Trump administration.

text:
“Chris
 Cuomo, in his interview with Sen. Blumenthal, never asked him about his
 long-term lie about his brave "service" in Vietnam. FAKE NEWS!”
analysis:
Cuomo’s
 first question to Blumenthal was: “What is your response to the 
president of the United States saying you should not be believed because
 you misrepresented your military record in the past?” Blumenthal ducked
 the question, but contrary to Trump’s tweet, the issue was raised.

text:
“Despite
 what you hear in the press, healthcare is coming along great. We are 
talking to many groups and it will end in a beautiful picture!”
analysis:
The
 press is reporting reactions to the replacement plan from lawmakers and
 industry groups from all sides of the political spectrum. Conservative 
and liberal industry groups have opposed the plan, along with Democrats 
and some Republican lawmakers, both moderate and conservative.

text: “Despite so many false statements and lies, total and complete vindication...and WOW, Comey is a leaker!”
analysis:
The
 FBI's investigation into Russian influence on the election continues, 
so it is not yet a "vindication." Moreover, former FBI James B. Comey 
leaked one unclassified memo about his conversation with Trump, but 
Trump himself revealed these conversations existed in his letter firing 
Comey.

text:
“Questions
 were asked about why the CIA & FBI had to ask the DNC 13 times for 
their SERVER, and were rejected, still don't have it.”
analysis:
The
 FBI and the Democratic National Committee disagree on whether the FBI 
requested access to the DNC's servers. FBI Director James Comey 
testified to the Senate Intelligence Committee that the bureau made 
"multiple requests at different levels" to access DNC's servers, but the
 DNC said the FBI never requested access. The DNC ultimately allowed a 
private company to review its database and share findings with the FBI.

text:
“Fake
 News said 17 intel agencies when actually 4 (had to apologize). Why did
 Obama do NOTHING when he had info before election?”
analysis:
On
 Jan. 6, the leadership of the intelligence community --the FBI, 
National Security Agency, CIA and the Director of National Intelligence 
-- released a declassified report expressing "high confidence" in the 
CIA's judgement that Russia had meddled in the U.S. election. Senate and
 House committees led by Republicans have begun their own 
investigations, and at least one Republican lawmaker has called for the 
appointment of a special prosecutor. President Obama did confront the 
Russian president before the election and reportedly told him to 'knock 
it off.' The Obama administration also took the intelligence to the 
House and Senate leadership in the hope of bipartisan congressional 
action.

text:
“Sanctions
 were not discussed at my meeting with President Putin. Nothing will be 
done until the Ukrainian & Syrian problems are solved!”
analysis:
Sanctions
 were, indeed, mentioned in the context of election meddling, according 
to Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and Trump spokeswoman Sarah Huckabee
 Sanders.

text:
“My
 first order as President was to renovate and modernize our nuclear 
arsenal. It is now far stronger and more powerful than ever before....”
analysis:
Trump
 indeed gave an order to launch a nuclear posture review, but that is 
standard procedure for a new administration. (It was not his first 
order, but came seven days after he took office.) But he’s kidding 
himself — or misleading Americans — that much has changed in the nuclear
 arsenal since he took office in January. President Barack Obama 
actually launched a modernization effort expected to cost as much as $1 
trillion, and Trump so far has not deviated from that path. Given the 
expense, the long manufacturing times and the need for annual 
congressional appropriations, the timeline for nuclear modernization is 
decades, not days. Fact Checker rating:

text:
“Our
 country has been unsuccessfully dealing with North Korea for 25 years, 
giving billions of dollars & getting nothing. Policy didn't work!”
analysis:
Under
 the Bill Clinton accord with North Korea, between 1995 and 2003 the 
United States spent about $400 million supplying the fuel oil to North 
Korea that was required under the deal. An international consortium 
spent about $2.5 billion to replace the North’s plutonium reactor with 
two light-water reactors; the project was not completed before the deal 
collapsed by the money mostly went to South Korean and Japanese 
companies, not North Korea. The United States stopped paying food 
assistance to North Korea after 2011, with the exception of $1 million 
in humanitarian aid in January 2017 that was negotiated by outgoing 
Secretary of State John Kerry just before Trump was inaugurated. Total 
food assistance since 1995 was about $700 million. George W. Bush in 
2007-2008 provided about $150 million in fuel oil when engaged in 
negotiations.

text: “GREAT AGAIN: +235,000”
analysis:
The
 day the Bureau of Labor Statistics released its employment report for 
Trump's first full month in office, Trump retweeted Drudge Report: 
"GREAT AGAIN: +235,000." This was a clear flip-flop from the stance he 
held for many years prior to this jobs report. He repeatedly questioned 
the accuracy of BLS employment statistics, and called figures calculated
 by career economists as "phony." White House press secretary Sean 
Spicer was asked about this contradiction at a news briefing after the 
report’s release. His response: “I talked to the president prior to this
 and he said to quote him very clearly. They may have been phony in the 
past, but it’s very real now.”

text:
“The
 Roger Stone report on @CNN is false - Fake News. Have not spoken to 
Roger in a long time - had nothing to do with my decision.”
analysis:
Two
 days after this tweet, Roger Stone {said in an interview} on "The 
View": “I'm not going to contradict the president and I'm not going to 
say when I spoke to him — but I would say this, I have spoken to him 
very recently."

text: “James Comey leaked CLASSIFIED INFORMATION to the media. That is so illegal! ”
analysis:
Former
 FBI Director James Comey said that {the president's tweet about 
possible "tapes" of their conversations led him to believe there might 
be corroboration for the memos} that he had written while still FBI 
director. Comey took contemporaneous notes following each of his 
meetings with the president and president-elect, which he shared with 
the senior leadership of the FBI. Comey intentionally wrote these in a 
way that the information wouldn't be classified.

text:
“When
 I left Conference Room for short meetings with Japan and other 
countries, I asked Ivanka to hold seat. Very standard. Angela M agrees!”
analysis:
The
 administration has proposed eliminating major rules but much has not 
been finalized. Meanwhile, 124 regulations with an estimated cost of $32
 billion have been issued  in 2017.

text: “Why is the NFL getting massive tax breaks while at the same time disrespecting our Anthem, Flag and Country? Change tax law!”
analysis:
This
 statement needs context. In 2015, the NFL voluntarily gave up 
tax-exempt status. However, the league can still receive the tax breaks 
to build stadiums.

text:
“I
 am so proud of my daughter Ivanka. To be abused and treated so badly by
 the media, and to still hold her head so high, is truly wonderful!”
analysis:
Trump
 exaggerates by saying that Ivanka Trump was "abused and treated so 
badly by the media." His tweet was referring to news coverage about 
Nordstrom dropping her brand. There was no evidence that Nordstrom acted
 out of political considerations, or that news coverage attacked Ivanka 
Trump over the news. The company has maintained for months (including in
 internal emails) that it will base its decisions on sales performance. 
Internal records reviewed by the Wall Street Journal show the sales of 
Ivanka Trump's brand fell 32 percent at Nordstrom last fiscal year.

text:
“Regulations
 way down. 600,000+ new jobs added. Unemployment down to 4.3%. Business 
and economic enthusiasm way up- record levels!”
analysis:
Unemployment
 has been steadily declining since its peak in 2010. Moreover, Trump now
 uses data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics unemployment rate to say 
this, which is a flip-flop from his previous claims dismissing the BLS 
unemployment rate as "nonsense."

text:
“Stock
 Market has increased by 5.2 Trillion dollars since the election on 
November 8th, a 25% increase. Lowest unemployment in 16 years...”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before he was elected, he dismissed the 
stock-market performance under Obama as “artificial” and “a bubble." It 
is also a flip-flop to cite an unemployment rate he used to denounce as 
phony.

text:
“It
 would be really nice if the Fake News Media would report the virtually 
unprecedented Stock Market growth since the election. Need tax cuts”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before he was elected, he dismissed the 
stock-market performance under Obama as “artificial” and “a bubble." 
Moreover, the stock market highs were regularly reported by the news 
media.

text:
“With
 all of the Fake News coming out of NBC and the Networks, at what point 
is it appropriate to challenge their License? Bad for country!”
analysis: Television networks are not licensed, unlike individual TV stations.

text:
“It
 is about time that Roger Goodell of the NFL is finally demanding that 
all players STAND for our great National Anthem-RESPECT OUR COUNTRY,”
analysis:
Trump
 insists the NFL Commissioner demands that players stand for the anthem,
 but following his tweet the NFL released a statement noting that 
Trump's commentary "about the Commissioner’s position on the Anthem is 
not accurate.” NFL players are encouraged but not required to stand.

Trump
 fired off this tweet after NBC reported he called for a nearly tenfold 
increase in the U.S. nuclear arsenal during a July meeting. NBC stands 
by its reporting.

text:
“The
 crackdown on illegal criminals is merely the keeping of my campaign 
promise. Gang members, drug dealers & others are being removed!”
analysis:
Trump
 is referring to the recent arrests of undocumented immigrants convicted
 of crimes (“criminal aliens”). Trump takes credit for fulfilling his 
campaign promise of cracking down on illegal immigration, but these 
arrests are routine. ICE has always targeted dangerous criminals in 
enforcement priorities. The recent arrests, however, did include people 
who would not have fallen under narrowed enforcement priorities under 
Obama. Still, 25 percent of the arrests were of people who had lesser 
charges and noncriminal convictions and are not the gang members or drug
 dealers that he describes.Fact Checker rating:

text:
“While
 on FAKE NEWS @CNN, Bernie Sanders was cut off for using the term fake 
news to describe the network. They said technical difficulties!”
analysis:
This
 is not true. In an interview with Erin Burnett, Sen. Bernie Sanders 
(I-Vt.) made a joke about Trump labeling CNN as “fake news.” After he 
made the joke, the audio cut off, and CNN cut to a commercial. Upon 
returning from the commercial, Burnett picked up where they left: 
“Senator, you were just talking — joking — about CNN, fake news.” Then 
Sanders went on to criticize Trump’s labeling of CNN as “fake news.”

text:
“Great
 win in Kansas last night for Ron Estes, easily winning the 
Congressional race against the Dems, who spent heavily & predicted 
victory!”
analysis:
Three
 things in this tweet are false. Estes, seeking a congressional seat 
long held by Republicans, did not have an easy win, Democrats did not 
spend heavily (Republicans did) and Democrats did not predict victory.

text:
“Again,
 the story that there was collusion between the Russians & Trump 
campaign was fabricated by Dems as an excuse for losing the election.”
analysis:
The
 information on Russian efforts to sway the 2016 election was developed 
by the intelligence community and published in a declassified report, in
 which the agencies said they had "high confidence" it was correct.

text:
“When
 James Clapper himself, and virtually everyone else with knowledge of 
the witch hunt, says there is no collusion, when does it end?”
analysis:
Trump
 goes too far in attributing such a comment to James Clapper, the former
 director of national intelligence (DNI). Clapper told the Senate 
Judiciary Committee that he was not aware of evidence showing collusion 
between members of the Trump campaign and the Russians. Clapper also 
said he was not aware of the FBI's investigation into the collusion 
until then-FBI Director James Comey revealed it on March 20, 2017. The 
FBI director has discretion to keep such counterintelligence 
investigations closely held, and only notify the DNI when appropriate, 
Clapper said.

text:
“China
 just agreed that the U.S. will be allowed to sell beef, and other major
 products, into China once again. This is REAL news!”
analysis:
China
 had already agreed to allow the sale of U.S. beef under a deal brokered
 by the Obama administration. The only thing new was that a definite 
date was set for when sales would begin.

text: “Congratulations! 'First New Coal Mine of Trump Era Opens in Pennsylvania'”
analysis:
Trump
 takes credit for a new mine opening up, but the digging of this coal 
mine began two months before the presidential election. Moreover, these 
mines are for metallurgical coal, which is used to make steel. It's not 
relevant in the context of the Paris agreement, in which this claim was 
made, because the agreement has to do with carbon emissions from thermal
 coal, which produces heat and electricity.Fact Checker rating:

text:
“ISIS
 is on the run & will soon be wiped out of Syria & Iraq, illegal
 border crossings are way down (75%) & MS 13 gangs are being 
removed.”
analysis:
Trump
 is referring to the decline in apprehensions along the Southwest 
border, from December 2016 through April 2017. Indeed, apprehensions 
have declined dramatically, despite seasonal trends. While the decline 
can be attributed in part to his anti-illegal immigration rhetoric on 
the campaign trail, the numbers are less impressive when you compare 
them to the first full month under the Trump presidency. From February 
2017 (the first full month of his presidency) through June 2017, 
apprehensions only declined 8 percent. Further, apprehensions are 
increasing again after bottoming out in April.

text:
“My
 son Donald did a good job last night. He was open, transparent and 
innocent. This is the greatest Witch Hunt in political history. Sad!”
analysis:
Donald
 Trump Jr. only released the emails facing a pending report on the 
content of the emails by the New York Times. Moreover, Trump exaggerates
 by calling the Trump-Russia stories the "greatest Witch Hunt in 
political history." For context: The Government Accountability Office 
concluded that the equivalent of $132 million was spent on independent 
probes during Bill Clinton's presidency, culminating in the impeachment 
trial in the Senate that left him in office.

text: “Remember, when you hear the words 'sources say' from the Fake Media, often times those sources are made up and do not exist.”
analysis:
Trump's
 stance on anonymous sources is inconsistent. He condemns them publicly,
 yet his White House consistently talks to media anonymously. Moreover, 
Trump himself shares stories on Twitter that are based on information 
provided by anonymous sources.

text: “Why aren't the same standards placed on the Democrats. Look what Hillary Clinton may have gotten away with. Disgraceful!”
analysis:
While
 there are some similarities between the Hillary Clinton's campaign's 
interactions with Ukrainians and Trump campaign's interactions with 
Russians, there are {key differences} that make it hard to compare the 
two. If Trump is referring to Clinton's handling of classified 
information as secretary of state, the FBI found that while she was 
"extremely careless," the agency found no evidence of intentional 
misconduct.

text: “Stock market hits another high with spirit and enthusiasm so positive. Jobs outlook looking very good! #MAGA”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before he was elected, he dismissed the 
stock-market performance under Obama as “artificial” and “a bubble." He 
also previously dismissed jobs numbers as a phony statistic.

text:
“The
 W.H. is functioning perfectly, focused on HealthCare, Tax Cuts/Reform 
& many other things. I have very little time for watching T.V.”
analysis: The president routinely live-tweets as he watches cable news.

text:
“2
 million more people just dropped out of ObamaCare. It is in a death 
spiral. Obstructionist Democrats gave up, have no answer = resist!”
analysis:
The
 Affordable Care Act is not on a "death spiral" and is expected to 
remain stable for the foreseeable future, according to the Congressional
 Budget Office.

text:
“A.G.
 Lynch made law enforcement decisions for political purposes...gave 
Hillary Clinton a free pass and protection. Totally illegal!”
analysis:
There
 are not enough facts to support the allegation in this tweet that 
former Attorney General Loretta Lynch did something "totally illegal" in
 the Clinton email investigation.

text:
“Crooked
 Hillary Clinton blames everybody (and every thing) but herself for her 
election loss. She lost the debates and lost her direction!”
analysis:
Credible,
 independent public opinion polls largely found Hillary Clinton won the 
three debates. In her book, Clinton repeatedly cited mistakes she had 
made in the race against Trump.

text:
“The
 Democrats ObamaCare is imploding. Massive subsidy payments to their pet
 insurance companies has stopped. Dems should call me to fix!”
analysis: The Affordable Care Act is expected to remain stable for the foreseeable future, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

text:
“The
 real story here is why are there so many illegal leaks coming out of 
Washington? Will these leaks be happening as I deal on N.Korea etc?”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before becoming president, Trump heartily 
endorsed WikiLeaks and the release of classified information, 
particularly about his then-rival Hillary Clinton. During a July 2016 
news conference, Trump even called on Russia to hack Clinton’s email 
account. Now, facing information leaks out of his own administration 
(including information that led to the resignation of national security 
adviser Michael Flynn), Trump decided it’s a bad thing.

text: “JOBS, JOBS, JOBS!”
analysis:
In
 this tweet, Trump included photos of the Bureau of Labor Statistics's 
employment report for Trump's first full month in office. This was a 
clear flip-flop from the stance he held for many years prior to this 
jobs report. He repeatedly questioned the accuracy of BLS employment 
statistics, and called figures calculated by career economists as 
"phony." White House press secretary Sean Spicer was asked about this 
contradiction at a news briefing after the report’s release. His 
response: “I talked to the president prior to this and he said to quote 
him very clearly. They may have been phony in the past, but it’s very 
real now.”

text:
“So
 impt Rep Senators, under leadership of @SenateMajLdr McConnell get 
healthcare plan approved. After 7yrs of O'Care disaster, must happen! ”
analysis:
To
 put it in context, the number of people affected by premium increases 
is just one-fourteenth the size of the employment-based health-insurance
 market-- and eight out of ten people in the Obamacare exchanges receive
 subsidies to shield them from premium increases. Moreover, some of the 
initial steps taken by the Trump administration have helped worsen the 
problems in the individual insurance market — allowing Trump to create a
 self-fulfilling prophecy.

text:
“The
 Obstructionist Democrats have given us (or not fixed) some of the worst
 trade deals in World History. I am changing that fast!”
analysis: It was actually George H.W. Bush, a Republican, who negotiated the NAFTA deal that Trump hates so much.

text:
“The
 Obstructionist Democrats have given us (or not fixed) some of the worst
 trade deals in World History. I am changing that fast!”
analysis:
Many
 trade deals had the support of Republicans. The North American Free 
Trade Agreement, for instance, was negotiated by George H.W. Bush and 
then approved by Congress with mostly Republican votes.

text:
“@Merck
 Pharma is a leader in higher & higher drug prices while at the same
 time taking jobs out of the U.S. Bring jobs back & LOWER PRICES!”
analysis:
Trump
 attacked Merck because its chief executive quit one of his CEO panels 
after the president's remarks on Charlottesville. But Merck actually has
 a relatively good record on drug prices. It is one of only a handful of
 big pharmaceutical companies to disclose the amount Merck actually 
receives for a drug after factoring in rebates and other discounts that 
drugmakers pay out.

text:
“Very
 proud of my Executive Order which will allow greatly expanded access 
and far lower costs for HealthCare. Millions of people benefit!”
analysis:
On
 Oct. 12 Trump signed an executive order eliminating cost-sharing 
reduction payments to insurance companies. He claims the order will 
result in lower costs, but according to a report from the Congressional 
Budget Office, premiums for 2018 would increase by 20% over the CBO's 
current baseline and by 25% over the 2020 projection. Additionally, 
about 1 million people would lose coverage in 2018.

text: “The real scandal here is that classified information is illegally given out by 'intelligence' like candy. Very un-American!”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before becoming president, Trump heartily 
endorsed WikiLeaks and the release of classified information, 
particularly about his then-rival Hillary Clinton. During a July 2016 
news conference, Trump even called on Russia to hack Clinton’s email 
account. Now, facing information leaks out of his own administration 
(including information that led to the resignation of national security 
adviser Michael Flynn), Trump decided it’s a bad thing.

text:
“Information
 is being illegally given to the failing @nytimes & @washingtonpost 
by the intelligence community (NSA and FBI?).Just like Russia”
analysis: Actually, The Post is doing great. The Times, like The Post, has seen spikes in audience and subscribers.

text:
“Does
 anybody really believe that a reporter, who nobody ever heard of, "went
 to his mailbox" and found my tax returns? @NBCNews  FAKE NEWS!”
analysis:
The
 reporter in question, David Cay Johnston, has won a Pulitzer Prize and 
covered Trump when he was in the gambling industry. Johnston says Trump 
used to call him at home.

text:
“Stock
 Market hit another all-time high yesterday - despite the Russian hoax 
story! Also, jobs numbers are starting to look very good!”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before he was elected, he dismissed the 
stock-market performance under Obama as “artificial” and “a bubble." He 
also previously dismissed jobs numbers as a phony statistic. Moreover, 
Trump again calls the Russia story a "hoax" regardless of any new 
development, even ones with documented proof (like his son's meeting 
with a Russian attorney).

text:
“For
 every CEO that drops out of the Manufacturing Council, I have many to 
take their place. Grandstanders should not have gone on. JOBS!”
analysis: One day later, the chief executives disbanded the panels.

text:
“With
 the ridiculous Filibuster Rule in the Senate, Republicans need 60 votes
 to pass legislation, rather than 51. Can't get votes, END NOW!”
analysis:
The
 Senate was already working through the reconciliation process, which 
requires a 51-vote majority, to pass the Obamacare repeal and replace 
bill.

text:
“ESPN
 is paying a really big price for its politics (and bad programming). 
People are dumping it in RECORD numbers. Apologize for untruth!”
analysis:
ESPN's
 May 2017 survey {found} that of the viewers who see a political bias on
 the network, "30 percent actually believe ESPN expresses a conservative
 viewpoint. Most importantly, even those who identify as conservative 
(or Republican) actually rate ESPN’s overall performance higher than 
those groups had in October" 2016. Moreover, ESPN was the "highest-rated
 full-time cable network among Men and Adults aged 18-34, 18-49 and 
25-54," it found.

text:
“We
 have made more progress in the last nine months against ISIS than the 
Obama Administration has made in 8 years.Must be proactive & nasty!”
analysis:
By
 just about every metric, this is not correct. Obama set up virtually 
all the structure that did the key fighting under Trump, and more land 
was captured, fighters trained and munitions dropped under Obama than 
under Trump. The basic plan of attack in 2017 was also developed under 
Obama, though Trump appears to have speeded up the tempo. Fact Checker rating:

text:
“Leaking,
 and even illegal classified leaking, has been a big problem in 
Washington for years. Failing @nytimes (and others) must apologize!”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before becoming president, Trump heartily 
endorsed WikiLeaks and the release of classified information, 
particularly about his then-rival Hillary Clinton. During a July 2016 
news conference, Trump even called on Russia to hack Clinton’s email 
account. Now, facing information leaks out of his own administration 
(including information that led to the resignation of national security 
adviser Michael Flynn), Trump decided it’s a bad thing.

text: “The spotlight has finally been put on the low-life leakers! They will be caught!”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before becoming president, Trump heartily 
endorsed WikiLeaks and the release of classified information, 
particularly about his then-rival Hillary Clinton. During a July 2016 
news conference, Trump even called on Russia to hack Clinton’s email 
account. Now, facing information leaks out of his own administration 
(including information that led to the resignation of national security 
adviser Michael Flynn), Trump decided it’s a bad thing.

text:
“Stock
 market hits new high with longest winning streak in decades. Great 
level of confidence and optimism - even before tax plan rollout!”
analysis:
This
 is a flip-flop for Trump. Before he was elected, he dismissed the 
stock-market performance under Obama as “artificial” and “a bubble."

text: “Great progress on healthcare. Improvements being made - Republicans coming together!”
analysis:
Not
 exactly. The day of this tweet, the House Budget Committee recommended 
changes to the GOP health-care bill that reflected concerns among 
conservative critics unhappy with the proposed legislation. Moderate 
Republicans have also expressed opposition, while deep concerns remain 
among Republicans in the Senate.

text:
“I
 did what was an almost an impossible thing to do for a 
Republican-easily won the Electoral College! Now Tax Returns are brought
 up again?”
analysis:
This
 is not correct. Every Republican president since Rutherford B. Hayes in
 1876 won a larger share of the electoral college votes than Trump, with
 the exception of George W. Bush and Richard Nixon.

text:
“Why
 would I call China a currency manipulator when they are working with us
 on the North Korean problem? We will see what happens!”
analysis: This is a flip flop. Throughout the campaign, Trump falsely blamed China for being a “world champion” of devaluing the yuan.

text: “I am being investigated for firing the FBI Director by the man who told me to fire the FBI Director! Witch Hunt”
analysis:
Trump
 has said he was going to fire James B. Comey as FBI director even 
before Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein recommended it.

text: “Great news! #MAGA Rasmussen reports 50% approval index June 16, 2017”
analysis:
The
 Rasmussen Presidential Tracking poll did show President Trump with a 
50% approval rating on Friday, June 16, but it appears to be an outlier,
 given the other polls show Trump at 40 percent or lower.

text:
“The
 ABC/Washington Post Poll, even though almost 40% is not bad at this 
time, was just about the most inaccurate poll around election time!”
analysis:
Independent
 researchers who examined polls from the election season and found that 
the ABC News/Washington Post poll was among the polls that were closest 
to the final result. Moreover, the poll that Trump was referring to 
found that his overall approval rating dropped to 36 percent from 42 
percent, and his disapproval rating rose five points to 58 percent.

text:
“HillaryClinton
 can illegally get the questions to the Debate & delete 33,000 
emails but my son Don is being scorned by the Fake News Media?”
analysis:
Trump
 overstates the disclosure about Clinton reportedly getting a single 
debate question. During the Democratic primaries, a debate was held in 
Flint, Mich., to focus on the water crisis. Donna Brazile, then a CNN 
analyst, sent an email to the Clinton campaign saying that a woman with a
 rash from lead poisoning was going to ask what Clinton as president 
could do the help the people of Flint. There’s no indication Clinton was
 told this information, but in any case it’s a pretty obvious question 
for a debate being held in Flint.

text:
“Amazon
 is doing great damage to tax paying retailers. Towns, cities and states
 throughout the U.S. are being hurt - many jobs being lost!”
analysis:
Amazon
 since April has collected sales taxes on every product it sells in 
every state that has a tax. Amazon leaves it up to third-party sellers 
to collect state sales tax.

text:
“Rather
 than putting pressure on the businesspeople of the Manufacturing 
Council & Strategy & Policy Forum, I am ending both. Thank you 
all!”
analysis:
Trump
 tried to claim that he had disbanded his chief executive panels, but 
this tweet came after he was told CEOs had quit in response to his 
Charlottesville remarks.

text: “THANK YOU @MayorGimenez for following the RULE OF LAW! Sanctuary cities make our country LESS SAFE!”
analysis:
There’s
 no evidence that "sanctuary" policies had anything to do with crime 
trends in Miami-Dade County. Mayor Carlos Gimenez said the county can't 
attribute its drop in crimes just to its reversal of its sanctuary 
policy. Instead, Gimenez pointed to various efforts the county took to 
decrease its crime rate using new tactics and neighborhood-based crime 
prevention, such as creating job-training programs for high-crime areas.

text:
“The
 super Liberal Democrat in the Georgia Congressioal race tomorrow wants 
to protect criminals, allow illegal immigration and raise taxes!”
analysis:
Jon
 Ossoff, the Democrat Trump is referring to, supports a comprehensive 
immigration bill that allows a "path to legal status" for undocumented 
people (excluding felons) living in the country. But he also said he 
supports strong border security. As PolitiFact found, this is not the same as "allowing illegal immigration. On taxes, factcheck.org found
 that Ossoff has proposed to simplify the tax code, and that “in order 
to lower tax rates, we can eliminate carve-outs and special treatment in
 the tax code that privilege large organizations at the expense of small
 businesses.”

text:
“Most
 politicians would have gone to a meeting like the one Don jr attended 
in order to get info on an opponent. That's politics!”

“Study
 what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when 
caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!”
analysis:
The
 president repeats a myth that has long been debunked by historians. 
There is no evidence that Gen. John J. Pershing -- the only American 
general to receive six stars during his lifetime -- committed the war 
crime of shooting 50 Muslim terrorists after dipping the bullets in 
pig's blood. In fact, Pershing de-escalated the conflict because he 
found that escalating counterterrorism was ineffective during the 
Philippines insurgency in 1899-1913.

text:
“I
 spoke with President Moon of South Korea last night. Asked him how 
Rocket Man is doing. Long gas lines forming in North Korea. Too bad!”
analysis:
This
 is doubtful. According to analysts in touch with North Korean 
residents, there were no obvious signs that the heightened sanctions led
 to long lines for gas, {The Washington Post reported.}

text: “Any increase in ObamaCare premiums is the fault of the Democrats for giving us a "product" that never had a chance of working.”
analysis:
This
 is misleading. Trump signed an executive order on Oct. 12 ending 
cost-sharing reduction payments to insurance companies. In August, the 
Congressional Budget Office estimated that without CSR payments, 
premiums for 2018 would increase by 20% over the CBO's current baseline 
and by 25% over the 2020 projection.

text:
“Germany
 owes vast sums of money to NATO & the United States must be paid 
more for the powerful, and very expensive, defense it provides to 
Germany!”
analysis:
Germany
 provides in-kind services for the U.S. bases, and the cost of running 
them is a pittance of the U.S. militraty bases. Germany owes no money to
 NATO, but has not yet acheived a goal, set for 2026, to spend at least 
two percent of its gross domestic product on defense.

text:
“The
 weak illegal immigration policies of the Obama Admin. allowed bad MS 13
 gangs to form in cities across U.S. We are removing them fast!”
analysis:
The
 MS-13 gang far predates Obama, and has been active since the 1980s. 
According to the Congressional Research Service in 2005 and 2008, the 
gang had spread across the country since the 1980s. Moreover, the 
Immigration and Customs Enforcement under Trump has been arresting an 
increasing number of noncriminals, indicating that it's not just the 
gang members that are being targeted by his administration.

text:
“Democrat
 Jon Ossoff would be a disaster in Congress. VERY weak on crime and 
illegal immigration, bad for jobs and wants higher taxes. Say NO”
analysis:
Jon
 Ossoff, the Democrat Trump is referring to, supports a comprehensive 
immigration bill that allows a "path to legal status" for undocumented 
people (excluding felons) living in the country. But he also said he 
supports strong border security. As PolitiFact found, this is not the 
same as "allowing illegal immigration." On taxes, factcheck.org found 
that Ossoff has proposed to simplify the tax code, and that “in order to
 lower tax rates, we can eliminate carve-outs and special treatment in 
the tax code that privilege large organizations at the expense of small 
businesses.”

text:
“Republicans
 must get out today and VOTE in Georgia 6. Force runoff and easy win! 
Dem Ossoff will raise your taxes-very bad on crime & 2nd A.”
analysis:
Jon
 Ossoff, the Democrat Trump is referring to, supports a comprehensive 
immigration bill that allows a "path to legal status" for undocumented 
people (excluding felons) living in the country. But he also said he 
supports strong border security. As PolitiFact found, this is not the 
same as "allowing illegal immigration." On taxes, factcheck.org found 
that Ossoff has proposed to simplify the tax code, and that “in order to
 lower tax rates, we can eliminate carve-outs and special treatment in 
the tax code that privilege large organizations at the expense of small 
businesses.”

text: #BuyAmericanHireAmerican Watch➡️http://45.wh.gov/npcpYM”
analysis:
Trump
 now calls for Americans to “buy American, hire American.” But this is 
misleading. Trump has a long history of outsourcing a variety of his own
 products. The Fact Checker has counted a total of 12 countries where 
Trump products were manufactured (China, the Netherlands, Mexico, India,
 Turkey, Slovenia, Honduras, Germany, Bangladesh, Indonesia, Vietnam and
 South Korea).

text:
“With
 all of the illegal acts that took place in the Clinton campaign & 
Obama Administration, there was never a special counsel appointed!”
analysis:
Trump
 repeatedly says he believed Hillary Clinton should face criminal 
charges for her use of a private email server as secretary of state, and
 that Clinton committed an illegal act. But then-FBI Director James 
Comey said his investigators did not find intentional mishandling of 
classified information, and did not recommend criminal charges.

text: “This is the single greatest witch hunt of a politician in American history!”
analysis:
The
 appointment of a special counsel is just the beginning of a process. 
The Government Accountability Office concluded that the equivalent of 
$132 million was spent on independent probes during Bill Clinton's 
presidency, culminating in the impeachment trial in the Senate that left
 him in office. At this point, it's a bit premature for Trump to make 
this claim.

text:
“The
 new Rasmussen Poll, one of the most accurate in the 2016 Election, just
 out with a Trump 50% Approval Rating.That's higher than O's #'s!”
analysis:
The
 Rasmussen Presidential Tracking poll did show President Trump with a 
50% approval rating on Friday, June 16, but it appears to be an outlier,
 given the other polls show Trump at 40 percent or lower. Moreover, on 
June 16, 2009, then-President Barack Obama had a 56% approval rating in 
the Rasmussen. While Rasmussen came close to predicting Hillary 
Clinton's margin of victroy in the popular vote -- which Trump has 
disputed -- the poll also predicted Clinton would win the Electoral 
College vote.

text: “RT @FoxNews: New Poll Shows @POTUS Approval at 50 Percent.”
analysis:
This
 was not a Fox News poll. The Rasmussen Presidential Tracking poll did 
show President Trump with a 50% approval rating on Friday, June 16, but 
it appears to be an outlier, given the other polls show Trump at 40 
percent or lower.

text:
“Fake
 News story of secret dinner with Putin is 'sick.' All G 20 leaders, and
 spouses, were invited by the Chancellor of Germany. Press knew!”
analysis:
News
 media did not say it was a secret dinner. It was a previously 
undisclosed one-hour meeting, accompanied only by Putin's translator.

text: “As I have always said, let ObamaCare fail and then come together and do a great healthcare plan. Stay tuned!”
analysis:
The
 Affordable Care Act is expected to remain stable for the foreseeable 
future, according to the Congressional Budget Office. Moreover, Trump 
only backed off of his pledge to repeal and replace Obamacare after he 
supported the failed attempts in both chambers of Congress to push 
through the legislation.

text:
“The
 Senate must go to a 51 vote majority instead of current 60 votes. Even 
parts of full Repeal need 60. 8 Dems control Senate. Crazy!”
analysis:
The
 Senate was already working through the reconciliation process, which 
requires a 51-vote majority, to pass the Obamacare repeal and replace 
bill. The various proposals never got more than 49 votes, so Trump's 
complaint makes little sense.

text:
“The
 Obstructionist Democrats make Security for our country very difficult. 
They use the courts and associated delay at all times. Must stop!”
analysis:
The
 judicial system is an equal branch of government, intended by the 
framers to be a check on the executive and legislative branches.

text:
“Radical
